Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH3121 - Mathematical Methods and Partial Differential Equations","description":"

This course builds on MATH2120 Mathematical Methods for Differential Equations in that it is concerned with ways of solving the (usually partial) differential equations that arise mainly in physical, biological and engineering applications.


Analytical methods have considerable intrinsic interest, but their importance for applications is the driving motive behind this course. The main analytical tools developed in this course can be thought of as generalisations of the Fourier and power series representations of functions studied in MATH2120. This leads to new types of functions and to practical methods for solving differential equations. We will pay special attention to functions defined on infinite domains.


The course begins by characterising different partial differential equations (PDEs), and exploring similarity solutions and the method of characteristics to solve them. The Fourier transform, the natural extension of a Fourier series expansion is then investigated. For functions of time, the Fourier transform corresponds to the “spectrum” of the function or signal in the problem in the frequency domain. Closely related to the Fourier transform is the Laplace transform which is particularly useful for solving the initial value PDEs that arise in many physical applications. Although contour integration is an intrinsic part of using these transforms, only brief references to complex variable methods will be made.


Transforms give a wide insight into the behaviour of a function and suggests other possibilities for the integral representation of solutions of PDEs. By exploiting certain special solutions of a given linear PDE we eventually obtain the idea of a Green's function for the PDE and a corresponding integral form for the solution. The power of Green's functions can be observed in their use as the inverses of differential operators on both infinite and bounded domains.


Frequently it is not possible to evaluate in closed form the Fourier, Laplace or Green’s function integrals appearing in the solution of the given PDE. All is not lost as we can still explore the asymptotic behaviour of these integrals at large parameter values and obtain physically useful information on the solution of the underlying problem.

It is an assignment on solution methods of optimization problems and may involve modelling practical problems and writing a short report. Due in week 10.

Assignments will give an opportunity for students to try their hand at more difficult problems requiring more than one line of argument and also introduce them to aspects of the subject which are not explicitly covered in lectures. The assignment will also require a student to draw together several topics in the course.

Feedback will be made available on the assignment paper.

contentlets.description: Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering. This course looks at the formulation of optimization problems as mathematical problems, characterizing solutions using necessary and/or sufficient optimality conditions and modern numerical methods and software for solving the problems. Both finite dimensional problems which involve a vector of variables, including linear and nonlinear programming, and infinite dimensional problems where the variables are functions, including optimal control problems, are covered.
contentlets.title: Optimization

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH3171 - Linear and Discrete Optimization Modelling","description":"

Optimization is the mathematical problem of finding a decision to achieve the best possible outcome while satisfying certain restrictions. Linear programs, conic linear programs and discrete optimization problems arise in a myriad of applications: electricity markets, airlines, logistics, public transport, international shipping, mining, finance, engineering, and data science. This course will provide an introduction to the basic mathematical theory, modelling techniques, computational methods and selected applications of linear, conic and discrete optimization.

contentlets.description: A dynamical system is any system whose state changes as a function of time.  This course studies the regular and irregular behaviour of nonlinear dynamical systems, concentrating on ordinary differential equations (ODEs) and their solutions. Topics from the theory of ODEs include: existence and uniqueness theorems;  linear ODEs with constant and periodic coefficients and Floquet theory; linearization and stability analysis; perturbation methods; bifurcation theory; phase plane analysis for autonomous systems. The theory is illustrated with applications to physical, biological and ecological systems. In addition, a selection from the dynamical concepts: Hamiltonian dynamics, resonant oscillations, chaotic systems, Lyapunov exponents, Poincare maps, homoclinic tangles.
contentlets.title: Dynamical Systems and Chaos

contentlets.description: The mathematical modelling and theory of problems arising in the flow of fluids, the oceans and the global climate; Cartesian tensors, kinematics, mass conservation, vorticity, Navier-Stokes equation; topics from inviscid and viscous fluid flow, gas dynamics, sound waves, water waves.The dynamics underlying the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans are detailed using key concepts such as geostrophy, the deformation radius and the conservation of potential vorticity. The role of Rossby waves, shelf waves, turbulent boundary layers and stratification is discussed. The atmosphere-ocean system as a global heat engine for climate variablity is examined using models for buoyant forcing, quasi-geostrophy and baroclinic instability.
contentlets.title: Fluids, Oceans and Climate

Finance","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2022/MATH5335","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"MATH5335","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3311 - Computational Mathematics for Finance","description":"

In the end, finance is concerned with making definite numerical recommendations which frequently can only be made by analysing sophisticated models using high-speed computers. This course studies the design, implementation and use of computer programs to solve practical mathematical problems of relevance to finance, insurance and risk management. A review of MATLAB, floating point numbers, rounding error and computational complexity. A selection of topics from: approximation and parameter estimation, Fourier series and the FFT, finite difference approximations, partial differential equations (heat equation), sparse linear systems, non-linear algebraic equations, trees, Monte Carlo methods and simulation, random numbers and variance reduction, numerical integration. Computing environments for mathematical finance. Practical examples and programming assignments using MATLAB.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5a248dc4dbb9b890be4672f5f39619d9","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Assignment is an ongoing assessment which is comprised of four parts, with part i due in Week 2i for i ∈ {1,2,3,4}. It can be done in groups comprised of 1,2,3 or 4 members. The contribution of each member must be specified (as a percentage).

The assignments will have a written and a computing component, and will emphasise basic Matlab programming and will also provide a preview of topics to be covered during lectures later in the course. This task will test student's skill at synthesising mathematical theory and practical computation, and at interpreting and presenting numerical results.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5a248dc4dbb9b890be4672f5f39619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory test in week 9 will take place in the computer lab under exam conditions. Students will have to write several short Matlab scripts and functions to solve simpler versions of the lab exercises.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"92248dc4dbb9b890be4672f5f39619df","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

A two-hour exam.

The final exam will mainly test student's mathematical understanding of the numerical methods discussed in lectures, and of their application in a financial context.

","learning_outcomes":[],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"da248dc4dbb9b890be4672f5f39619dd","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/MATH3311.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH3361 - Stochastic Differential Equations: Theory, Applications, and Numerical Methods","description":"

Stochastic differential equation models play a prominent role in a range of application areas, including biology, chemistry, epidemiology, mechanics, microelectronics, economics, and finance. This course studies the theory and applications of stochastic differential equations, the design and implementation on computers of numerical methods for solving these practical mathematical equations. The course will start with a background knowledge of random variables, Brownian motion, Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process. Other topics studied include: stochastic integrals, the Euler-Maruyama method, Milstein's higher order method, stability and convergence.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"73244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194c","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The Final Exam will mainly test mathematical understanding of the numerical methods discussed in lectures, but will also include some questions on scientific computing.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"04344108dbb9b890be4672f5f3961962","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Written test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The written test is in two parts. 

  • Part one is taken in week 4 and covers topics on probability spaces, random variables, stochastic processes, and stochastic integrals.
  • Part two is taken in week 8 and covers Euler-Maruyama and Milstein methods for stochastic ODEs.

The tutorial component of the Class Work will assess understanding of the relevant mathematical concepts, and student's competence at routine calculations. Feedback will be given when marks are released.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7f244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"73244108dbb9b890be4672f5f3961951","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

The assignment due in week 9 will have a computing component and a written component.

The Assignment will test students' skill at synthesising mathematical theory and practical computation, and at interpreting and presenting numerical results. Submissions will be returned to students with comments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"77244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7f244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7f244108dbb9b890be4672f5f396194e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7f244108dbb9b890be4672f5f3961955","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"15","description":"

The Lab test in week 7 will require students to write some short programs under exam conditions.

The lab component of the Class Work will assess students' ability to write and modify short Matlab programs, testing their knowledge of the language syntax and their understanding of standard programming constructs. Students will need to demonstrate within an hour lab test that they have the necessary skills to write codes to apply the methods learnt in lectures. Feedback will be given when marks are released.

Algorithms from numerical linear algebra are ubiquitous in scientific and statistical software. The theoretical component of the course aims to impart an understanding of how these algorithms work as well as an appreciation of their potential limitations. Familiar pencil-and-paper methods suitable for solving small problems by hand calculation must typically be modified or replaced by different approaches when faced with large problems whose solution is feasible only with the help of a computer. To illustrate the applications of numerical linear algebra, a variety of examples from statistics, data science and applied mathematics are described. The course includes a substantial computing component providing practical experience with widely used software libraries.

Higher Topology and Differential Geometry of Surfaces","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/undergraduate/courses/2022/MATH3760","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"inactive","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"MATH3760","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3531 - Topology and Differential Geometry","description":"

This major theme of this course is the study of properties of curves and surfaces that are preserved under changes: differentiable changes in differential geometry and continuous changes intopology. The differential geometry is treated as a continuation of vector calculus studied in earlier courses.


We begin with the study of curves in the plane and analyse what it means to be curved rather than straight, and then cover curves in space and how they curve and twist. We progresses to surfaces and how they bend both internally and externally and look at minimal surfaces and geodesics. We show why a map of the earth must be distorted in our study of Gauss' "Remarkable Theorem" and then cover the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem. In the last section, we cover the Euler characteristic and the platonic solids, Mobius bands and other surfaces and study the elementary combinatorial topology of surfaces. The course culminates in the complete classification of topological surfaces..


Note: Offered in even numbered years only.

Submitted and assessed with feedback on moodle within 10 working days.

Held in tutorial in week 4, covers the first third of the course. Test is returned with feedback and solution to students within one week. 

Students with a mark below 60% will be offered an opportunity to resit, with the resit mark capped at 60%.

To cover the whole course but with an emphasis on the final two thirds of the course (differential geometry and topology of surfaces).

Students have the opportunity to view their scripts in line with School and University policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7645cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7645cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619ad","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7e45cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fe45cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619b1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

due in week 5. Covers the first third of the course (differential geometry of curves).

Submitted and assessed with feedback on moodle within 10 working days.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7645cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619ac","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"fe45cd8cdbb9b890be4672f5f39619d1","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/MATH3531.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description:
This major theme of this course is the study of properties of curves and surfaces that are preserved under changes: differentiable changes in differential geometry and continuous changes intopology. The differential geometry is treated as a continuation of vector calculus studied in earlier courses.

We begin with the study of curves in the plane and analyse what it means to be curved rather than straight, and then cover curves in space and how they curve and twist. We progresses to surfaces and how they bend both internally and externally and look at minimal surfaces and geodesics. We show why a map of the earth must be distorted in our study of Gauss' "Remarkable Theorem" and then cover the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem. In the last section, we cover the Euler characteristic and the platonic solids, Mobius bands and other surfaces and study the elementary combinatorial topology of surfaces. The course culminates in the complete classification of topological surfaces..

Note: Offered in even numbered years only.
contentlets.title: Topology and Differential Geometry

The development of mathematical ideas has often been very slow and at times tortuous, but nearly always interesting. The finished product which is presented at secondary school and in University courses often hides much of the story which led to the development of the subject. This course looks at how mathematics was used and understood in ages past, and the long and storied history of how familiar mathematical concepts grew into their present form. This course will deepen your understanding of mathematics by comparing original sources such as ancient Mesopotamia, Greece, India or China with more modern mathematics of the last 150-200 years.

Students will be asked to take careful and neat notes of both in-class and online lectures, and this will be marked near the end of term. Marks will be graded 1-5 for evidence the student has 

  1.   watched and understood online material,
  2.   created of a useful resource for later use in their professional career as a High School teacher
  3.   made a serious attempt at any ad hoc problems posed during lectures (if such are set)

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3570 - Foundations of Calculus","description":"

What does it mean for a limit to exist? What does it mean for a function to be continuous or differentiable? There are functions which are continuous everywhere but differentiable nowhere! Are there functions whose integral does not exist? In this course, we look again at the essential concepts of limit, continuity, differentiability and integrability and try to place them on a sure footing. The syllabus includes material on sequences and series of real numbers and also of real valued functions. Although of general interest to those studying mathematics for its own sake, this course is of special relevance to those planning a career in secondary teaching.


MATH3570 is a compulsory component of the program for mathematics teachers.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"665505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bb","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Test","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Held in week 4.

The test will give students an opportunity to test their understanding of the basic concepts in the course and will provide students with some feedback.

Returned to students with comments and/or solutions in line with standard UNSW policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bf","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The final two hour examination will assess student mastery of the material covered in the lectures.

Mark returned as part of final mark. Usual UNSW and School rules for inspection of exam applies.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619c7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Examples portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Portfolio","value":"portfolio"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Mathematics is about important examples as well as theorems. Students need to be able to illustrate the theory with well-chosen examples. As the course progresses students will build up a small portfolio of their own examples and counterexamples with ongoing feedback.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"765505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619cc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Due in week 8.

The assignment will give an opportunity for students to try their hand at more difficult problems requiring more than one line of argument and also introduce them to aspects of the subject which are not explicitly covered in lectures.

Returned to students with comments and/or solutions in line with standard UNSW policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bd","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"aa5505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619bc","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a25505ccdbb9b890be4672f5f39619c3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/MATH3570.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3611 - Higher Analysis","description":"

Limits and continuity are the central concepts of calculus in one and several variables. These concepts can be extended to quite general situations. The simplest of these is when there is some way of measuring the distance between two objects. Some of the most important examples of these `metric spaces' occur as sets of functions, so this course looks at ways in which one might say that a sequence of functions converges. Taking these ideas one step further, we look at convergence which does not come from a generalised distance function. These are the ideas of point set topology. The course includes topics such as countability, continuity, uniform convergence and compactness, as well as an introduction to the core areas of function analysis.

A two-hour exam.

The final examination will assess student mastery of the material covered in the lectures. The exam will include questions requiring knowledge of the definitions, examples and theorems in the course, as well as problems to be solved using such knowledge.

contentlets.description:
Topology and differential geometry both deal with the study of shape: topology from a continuous and differential geometry from a differentiable viewpoint.
This course begins with a study of curves in the plane and in space focussing on how they bend. We then consider surfaces, studying the first and second fundamental forms introduced by Gauss, the various measures of curvature and what they mean for the external and internal appearance and properties of surfaces. We prove the important Gauss-Bonnet theorem and use it to examine topological properties of surfaces, such as the Euler Characteristic.

This course is part of the core Higher Pure Mathematics sequence MATH3711/MATH3611/MATH3701 which is designed to be taken in that order. In particular, it is strongly recommended that students have taken MATH3611 beforehand so they can get the most of it.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3711 - Higher Algebra","description":"

In Higher Algebra we examine some of the basic notions of modern algebra that arose in the late 19th and early 20th century. The most fundamental notion is that of a group, which is how mathematicians study symmetry. In this course groups are studied in detail both from an abstract point of view and also to study symmetry in geometry. The other important concept studied is that of a ring. The algebra of adding and multiplying matrices has many similarities with the algebra of numbers. The notion of rings generalises both these two examples. The course examines factorisation theory for certain rings.

contentlets.description: Coverage of the main parametric and non-parametric and techniques used in statistics. Uniformly minimum variance estimation. Cramer-Rao inequality, Lehmann-Scheffe theorem. Monotone likelihood ratio distributions and uniformly most powerful unbiased tests. Generalised likelihood ratio tests, exact tests and large sample tests. Bayesian point estimation, interval estimation and hypothesis testing. Robustness and bootstrap resampling. Order statistics, goodness of fit, contingency tables. Statistical inference based on ranks. One sample, two sample and k-sample problems, blocked data, independence and association.
contentlets.title: Statistical Inference

contentlets.description: Introduction to flexible and modern approaches to statistical modelling and statistical computing.  Theory, applications and computation for linear models, generalised linear models, the Bayesian linear model, nonparametric regression using kernel smoothers and smoothing splines, nonparametric density estimation and bandwidth selection.  Applications of simulation in statistical inference including Monte Carlo simulation, bootstrap methods, and Markov chain Monte Carlo.  Statistical packages include R or Splus.
contentlets.title: Statistical Modelling and Computing

contentlets.description: In this course you will develop skills important for the design and analysis of research in the social sciences and in market research. The specific focus will be on issues related to survey sampling, and questionnaire design and analysis. By the end of this course, you will be able to identify an appropriate survey design for a particular situation, estimate the required sample sizes to achieve a given level of precision, estimate key quantities of interest (typically expressed as averages, totals or ratios), and make inferences about key quantities using their sample estimates. In addition, you will be able to design a questionnaire suitable for answering a key research question, and analyse responses to a questionnaire using a range of modern techniques.
contentlets.title: Statistical Methods in Social and Market Research

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3841 - Statistical Analysis of Dependent Data","description":"

This course extends statistical modelling from independently distributed data to modelling dependence in observed data, and develops an understanding of basic distributions and models useful in practical situations. It continues with the development of statistical methods for analysis of dependent data arising in multivariate observations, time series and spatial processes, and also covers multivariate normal distribution, Hotelling's T-squared, Wishart distribution. It concludes with a study of time series models, stationary time series, ARMA and forecasting ARMA, spatial processes, sample semivariograms and Kriging.

Test is returned with feedback and solutions within 2 weeks.

Feedback will be provided at the tutorial by the Course Convenor and other students, if appropriate.

contentlets.description: This course focuses on the principles of good experimental design and the statistical tools appropriate for discrete valued data. Topics include factorial designs and their analysis, response surface designs for product and process optimization, random effects models and components of variance, exploratory and graphical analysis of data using modern statistical packages, data visualization, analysis of cross-tabulated data, logistic and Poisson regression for analysis of binary and count data and log-linear models for contingency tables.
contentlets.title: Experimental Design and Categorical Data

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH3871 - Bayesian Inference and Computation","description":"

After describing the fundamentals of Bayesian inference, this course will examine the specification of prior and posterior distributions, Bayesian decision theoretic concepts, the ideas behind Bayesian hypothesis tests, model choice and model averaging, and evaluate the  capabilities of several common model types, such as hierarchical and mixture models. An important part of Bayesian inference is the requirement to numerically evaluate complex integrals on a routine basis. Accordingly this course will also introduce the ideas behind Monte Carlo integration, importance sampling, rejection sampling, Markov chain Monte Carlo samplers such as the Gibbs sampler and the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm, and use of the WinBuGS posterior simulation software.

Each student will be required to satisfactorily answer at least one question over the course of the term during a lab, tutorial or lecture, with immediate feedback. The mark is awarded immediately on a satisfactory/non-satisfactory basis, and students will be given multiple options to respond. 

The questions are at a basic level for the course material and designed to ensure engagement and participation. Students are expected to take the initiative in responding.

contentlets.description: As for MATH3801 but in greater depth:Introduction to stochastic processes, that is, processes that evolve over time such as price fluctuations of a stock.   The course emphasises theory and applications, and covers discrete- and continuous-time Markov chains, Poisson processes and Brownian motion.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH3911 - Higher Statistical Inference","description":"

As for MATH3811 but in greater depth.


Coverage of the main parametric and non-parametric and techniques used in statistics. Uniformly minimum variance estimation. Cramer-Rao inequality, Lehmann-Scheffe theorem. Monotone likelihood ratio distributions and uniformly most powerful unbiased tests. Generalised likelihood ratio tests, exact tests and large sample tests. Bayesian point estimation, interval estimation and hypothesis testing. Robustness and bootstrap resampling. Order statistics, goodness of fit, contingency tables. Statistical inference based on ranks. One sample, two sample and k-sample problems, blocked data, independence and association.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH4001 - Mathematics and Statistics Honours Thesis","description":"

This course, taken three times over three consecutive terms, forms the thesis component of the honours streams for applied mathematics, pure mathematics, physical oceanography, quantitative risk or statistics. The three instances of the course form part of the one thesis/project.


For the thesis component, a student will undertake independent study in the appropriate area of applied mathematics, pure mathematics, physical oceanography, quantitative risk or statistics according to their honours stream. The student will be supervised by at least one member of the academic staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics, possibly jointly with an academic external to the School, or, with the permission of the Head of School, a suitable other person in a non-university research position. The student will write a thesis and give an oral presentation on the thesis to the appropriate department. 


Weekly honours seminars will be timetabled as part of the thesis courses. The main purpose of these seminars is to provide a forum for honours students to give an oral presentation of their work to, and receive feedback from, their peers, the honours coordinators and their supervisor(s). The seminars will also be used for other honours training purposes, such how to use and access mathematical and statistical literature, research methodology in mathematics and statistics and how to write mathematics and statistics.  


The written thesis will be assessed on four major areas:


  1. exposition
  2. literature coverage
  3. critical analysis and insight
  4. originality

The weighting of these components will depend on the type of thesis, as determined by discussion between the student and supervisor(s) when the topic is chosen. All theses are expected to address all four areas. 


Two academic staff members will assess the thesis. The supervisor(s) are expected to provide a report on the thesis but they may not be one of the two markers.


The written thesis mark will account for 90% of the final grade; the oral presentation for the other 10%. The final mark awarded will be decided at specially convened meetings. Students will receive a marker's report on their written thesis, outlining how the final mark was decided and possibly listing errors that ought to be corrected.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b9c5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619ae","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"90","description":"

A typewritten report on the thesis topic


The student's supervisor will provide feedback on draft versions. The thesis examiners' report will be made available to the students at the conclusion of the honours stream.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"35c5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"35c5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3dc5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619af","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"3dc5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"7dc5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

A talk of between 25 and 50 minutes given to the appropriate department within the School of Mathematics and Statistics.


Students will give shorter presentations throughout the year to the honours seminar, where immediate feedback will be provided. The final  presentation should be rehearsed with the supervisor. The mark for the presentation will not be given separately.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"35c5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3dc5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b1","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"f1c5c940dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b3","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/MATH4001.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

The final project report and seminar is independently assessed by at least two members of staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics and the average mark awarded unless there is a major discrepancy (5 marks or more). Any such discrepancy in the assigned marks is addressed at an appropriate Departmental Assessment Review meeting and the final mark decided by the Head of School of nominee.

A thorough study of a set of mathematics papers or some workplace problem of the student's choice. 



Notes:
1.  Available only to students for whom it forms part of their degree requirements.2.  Enrolment is subject to appropriate research and supervision resources being available. 3.  Students must have a WAM of 70 or higher in the first four (4) courses (24 UOC) of their program to be eligible to take this course. 


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"93c54d40dbf9b890be4672f5f396198b","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"100","description":"

MATH5005 and MATH5006 are assessed together as one 2 term project worth 12UoC. The same mark is entered for both.

\n

The final project report and seminar is independently assessed by at least two members of staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics and the average mark awarded unless there is a major discrepancy (5 marks or more). Any such discrepancy in the assigned marks is addressed at an appropriate Departmental Assessment Review meeting and the final mark decided by the Head of School of nominee.

contentlets.description:
A thorough study of a set of mathematics papers or some workplace problem of the student's choice. 


Notes:
1.  Available only to students for whom it forms part of their degree requirements.2.  Enrolment is subject to appropriate research and supervision resources being available. 3.  Students must have a WAM of 70 or higher in the first four (4) courses (24 UOC) of their program to be eligible to take this course.
contentlets.title: Advanced Mathematics Project A

A thorough study of a set of mathematics papers or some workplace problem of the student's choice. 



Notes: 1.  Available only to students for whom it forms part of their degree requirements. 2.  Enrolment is subject to appropriate research and supervision resources being available.  3.  Students must have a WAM of 70 or higher in the first four (4) courses (24 UOC) of their program to be eligible to take this course.

MATH5005 and MATH5006 are assessed together as one 2 term project worth 12UoC. The same mark is entered for both.

\n

The final project report and seminar are independently assessed by at least two members of staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics and the average mark awarded unless there is a major discrepancy (5 marks or more). Any such discrepancy in the assigned marks is addressed at an appropriate Departmental Assessment Review meeting and the final mark decided by the Head of School of nominee.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH5165 - Optimization","description":"

Optimization problems, in which one wants to find the values of variables to maximize or minimize an objective function subject to constraints on which variables are allowed, are common throughout the physical and biological sciences, economics, finance and engineering. This course looks at the formulation of optimization problems as mathematical problems, characterizing solutions using necessary and/or sufficient optimality conditions and modern numerical methods and software for solving the problems. Both finite dimensional problems which involve a vector of variables, including linear and nonlinear programming, and infinite dimensional problems where the variables are functions, including optimal control problems, are covered.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"1fd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961977","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

A two-hour exam covering everything in the course.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"17d58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1fd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d3d58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dbd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"dbd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1bd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Class test 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

A 50-minute test taken in class in week 4.

There will be short answer questions in which correct answers are sought and there will be some longer questions requiring clear and logical presentation of correct solutions as well as some simple proofs and verbal explanations.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"17d58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1fd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961978","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"d3d58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961986","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"dbd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f3961985","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1bd58180dbf9b890be4672f5f396198f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

It is an assignment on solution methods of optimization problems and may involve modelling practical problems and writing a short report.

Assignments will give an opportunity for students to try their hand at more difficult problems requiring more than one line of argument and also introduce them to aspects of the subject which are not explicitly covered in lectures. The assignment will also require a student to draw together several topics in the course.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5171 - Linear and Discrete Optimization Modelling","description":"

Optimization is the mathematical problem of finding a decision to achieve the best possible outcome while satisfying certain restrictions. Linear programs, conic linear programs and discrete optimization problems arise in a myriad of applications: electricity markets, airlines, logistics, public transport, international shipping, mining, finance, engineering, and data science. This course will provide an introduction to the basic mathematical theory, modelling techniques, computational methods and selected applications of linear, conic and discrete optimization.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5175 - Special Topics in Applied Mathematics A","description":"

This course gives an introduction to the theory of stochastic differential equations (SDEs), explains real-life applications, and introduces numerical methods to solve these equations. Stochastic differential equation models play a prominent role in a range of application areas, including biology, chemistry, epidemiology, mechanics, microelectronics, economics, and finance. With the ongoing development of powerful computers, there is a real need to solve these stochastic models. The corresponding SDEs generalise the ordinary deterministic differential equations (ODEs).


Similarly to (deterministic) ODEs, analytical solutions of SDEs are rare, and therefore, numerical approximations have to be developed.

Feedback will be given when marks are released.

Students will apply the theory and codes that they have learnt to solve a practical problem. Some harder questions requiring a comprehensive understanding of the course will be asked.

Submissions will be returned to students with comments.

Students will need to demonstrate that they understand the theory and know how to apply it.

Feedback will be given when marks are released.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"33560144dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33560144dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3b560144dbf9b890be4672f5f39619b8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"bb560144dbf9b890be4672f5f39619ba","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

The final exam assess students' overall comprehension of the course. The whole course content will be asked, but no question on coding will be asked. The exam will contain some star subquestions.

Students may inspect their exam in line with standard School and UNSW policy.

contentlets.description:
This course gives an introduction to the theory of stochastic differential equations (SDEs), explains real-life applications, and introduces numerical methods to solve these equations. Stochastic differential equation models play a prominent role in a range of application areas, including biology, chemistry, epidemiology, mechanics, microelectronics, economics, and finance. With the ongoing development of powerful computers, there is a real need to solve these stochastic models. The corresponding SDEs generalise the ordinary deterministic differential equations (ODEs).

Similarly to (deterministic) ODEs, analytical solutions of SDEs are rare, and therefore, numerical approximations have to be developed.
contentlets.title: Special Topics in Applied Mathematics A

For the research project component, a student will undertake independent study in the appropriate area of physical oceanography. The student will be supervised by at least one member of the academic staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics, possibly jointly with an academic external to the School, or a suitable person in a non-university research position. contentlets.description:
This course is taken three times over three consecutive terms, and forms the research project component of the Masters of Physical Oceanography 8518. The three instances of the course each form part of the one project.

For the research project component, a student will undertake independent study in the appropriate area of physical oceanography. The student will be supervised by at least one member of the academic staff of the School of Mathematics and Statistics, possibly jointly with an academic external to the School, or a suitable person in a non-university research position. The student will write a report and give an oral presentation on the project to the Physical Oceanography department.

The written report will be assessed on four major areas:

  1. exposition
  2. literature coverage
  3. critical analysis and insight
  4. originality

The weighting of these components will depend on the type of report, as determined by discussion between the student and supervisor(s) when the topic is chosen. All theses are expected to address all four areas. 

Two academic staff members will assess the thesis. The supervisor(s) are expected to provide a report on the thesis but they may not be one of the two markers.

The written thesis mark will account for 90% of the final grade; the oral presentation for the other 10%. The final mark awarded will be decided at specially convened meetings. Students will receive a marker's report on their written thesis, outlining how the final mark was decided and possibly listing errors that ought to be corrected.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5231 - Prediction and Inverse Modelling","description":"

This course is a graduate level overview of the mathematical foundations of inverse modelling and prediction and their application to real-world systems, primarily the ocean and atmosphere. The scientific emphasis is on the formal testing of models, formulated as rigorous hypotheses about the errors in all the information: dynamics, initial conditions, boundary conditions and data. Applications in meteorology, oceanography, and climate are presented in detail.

Please note: Some computing experience (R, Fortran, Maple, Matlab, or Python) is strongly recommended for this course.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"de764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Project Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"40","description":"

A final research project will test the ability of students to integrate and apply the facts, concepts, and theory introduced in the discussion sessions. Students will write a report to be submitted at the end of the course. Feedback will be provided in face-to-face consultations and in a written evaluation distributed to the student at the end of the course. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"16764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"12764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619dc","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 2 (due in Week 6) will cover the topic of Variational Assimilation. Marks will be awarded for approach, clarity of explanation, and, as required, appropriate referencing, not just the final result. Students will be provided feedback in written form as well as in person during face-to-face consultations. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"26764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619e5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 1 (due in Week 3) will cover the topics of Least Squares, Bayesian statistics, and Kalman filtering. Marks will be awarded for approach, clarity of explanation, and, as required, appropriate referencing, not just the final result. Students will be provided feedback in written form as well as in person during face-to-face consultations. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"16764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"1e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619d6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2e764944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619e1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 3 (due in Week 9) will cover the topic of Implementation of Data Assimilation methodologies. Marks will be awarded for approach, clarity of explanation, and, as required, appropriate referencing, not just the final result. Students will be provided feedback in written form as well as in person during face-to-face consultations.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5271 - Environmental Data Science and Statistics","description":"

This course is a graduate level overview of the applications of data science in an environmental context. Although applications and motivations will be drawn primarily from the ocean, atmospheric and climate sciences, the material covered will apply generally across various environmental and non-environmental science and industry areas.  A key distinction between this course and other data science offerings within the School of Mathematics and Statistics is an emphasis on practical real-world problems. These include practical approaches to data handling and quality control, consideration of real world examples of good and bad data science practice, the application of various statistical methods to real world data sets, the integration of statistical approaches with physically based forecast methods, and a project component involving independent exploration and exposition of cutting edge machine learning methods.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"43768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961986","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Data handling essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

The first week of the course will cover the largely qualitative subject of data handling. The aim of this section will be to encourage students to think critically about different challenges and considerations in environmental data science so a short essay will be prescribed (worth 10% of their overall mark) where student will be asked to determine key lessons learnt form one of a number of case studies. Essays will be due before week 3 via TurnItIn. 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"07768944dbf9b890be4672f5f396199c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Portfolio","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"50","description":"

Throughout the remainder of the course students will complete a portfolio involving the application and discussion of the various methods presented in the course. The portfolio will involve 3 specific tasks related directly to the course material and 1 additional task which is more open ended and will encourage the student to undertake independent exploration of data science methods. The portfolio will be worth 50% of the overall mark for the course (10% per specific task and 20% for a final project).

\n

Feedback will be given by lecturers and tutors for portfolio tasks both in tutorials and via the moodle workshop where appropriate. Final portfolios will be submitted (including completion of all 4 tasks) at the end of week 11.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f396199f","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

To assess student’s independent mastery of the course content and understanding of its key ideas, a final exam will be given worth 10% of the overall mark.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"87768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961996","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Folio peer review","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

To encourage collaboration, critical thinking and scepticism, students will peer review the first 3 tasks of the portfolio with the peer review task worth a total of 10% of the overall mark. Using the Moodle workshop feature, draft progressive portfolios will be submitted after odd weeks (3, 5 and 7) and feedback given by students after even weeks (4, 6 and 8). Reviewers will be asked to give feedback on initial attempts at tasks. Final versions of tasks 1-3 will be due after week 9 and reviewers will be given a final opportunity to assess whether all tasks have been completed satisfactorily. Summative assessment of peer reviews will depend on whether the final versions of reviewed portfolios are satisfactory and if not whether the reviewer gave appropriate and constructive feedback.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"47768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961988","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"4f768944dbf9b890be4672f5f3961987","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"87768944dbf9b890be4672f5f39619a5","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2022/MATH5271.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH5285 - Fluids, Oceans and Climate","description":"

The mathematical modelling and theory of problems arising in the flow of fluids, the oceans and the global climate. Cartesian tensors, kinematics, mass conservation, vorticity, Navier-Stokes equation. Topics from inviscid and viscous fluid flow, gas dynamics, sound waves, water waves. The dynamics underlying the circulation of the atmosphere and oceans are detailed using key concepts such as geostrophy, the deformation radius and the conservation of potential vorticity. The role of Rossby waves, shelf waves, turbulent boundary layers and stratification is discussed. The atmosphere-ocean system as a global heat engine for climate variablity is examined using models for buoyant forcing, quasi-geostrophy and baroclinic instability.

Engineering","description":"

Partial differential equations (PDEs) provide a natural mathematical description for many phenomena of interest in science and engineering. Such equations are often difficult or impossible to solve using purely analytical (pencil and paper) methods, especially for realistic industrial problems. This course introduces finite difference and finite element methods for elliptic and parabolic PDEs, and discusses key concepts such as stability, convergence and computational cost. Relevant techniques in numerical linear algebra are also discussed.


The course includes a substantial practical component dealing with the computer implementation of the algorithms used for solving partial differential equations.


Note: Students must have some prior experience with computer programming.

of Science","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"MATH5335 - Computational Mathematics for Finance","description":"

In the end finance is concerned with making definite numerical recommendations that frequently can only be obtained by analysing sophisticated models using high-speed computers. This course studies the design, implementation and use of computer programs to solve practical mathematical problems of relevance to finance, insurance and risk management.
It includes a review of MATLAB, floating point numbers, rounding error and computational complexity, and a selection of topics from: approximation and parameter estimation, Fourier series and the FFT, finite difference approximations, partial differential equations (Black-Scholes PDE), sparse linear systems, nonlinear algebraic equations, trees, Monte Carlo methods and simulation, random numbers and variance reduction, numerical integration.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d2a60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619ad","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Assignment is an ongoing assessment which is comprised of four parts, with part i due in Week 2i for i ∈ {1,2,3,4}. It can be done in groups comprised of 1,2,3 or 4 members. The contribution of each member must be specified (as a percentage).

The assignments will have a written and a computing component, and will emphasise basic Matlab programming and will also provide a preview of topics to be covered during lectures later in the course. This task will test student's skill at synthesising mathematical theory and practical computation, and at interpreting and presenting numerical results.

returned to students with comments and/or solutions in line with standard policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"96a60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ea60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ea60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1ea60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619c6","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Lab test","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The laboratory test in week 9 will take place in the computer lab under exam conditions. Students will have to write several short Matlab scripts and functions to solve simpler versions of the lab exercises.

returned to students with comments and/or solutions in line with standard policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"96a60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"9ea60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619ba","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ea60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619bb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"d2a60984dbf9b890be4672f5f39619c2","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

The final exam will mainly test student's mathematical understanding of the numerical methods discussed in lectures, and of their application in a financial context. It is a formal exam covering the content of the entire course.
Mark returned as part of final mark. Usual UNSW and School rules for inspection of exam applies.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5361 - Stochastic Differential Equations: Theory, Applications, and Numerical Methods","description":"

Stochastic differential equation models play a prominent role in a range of application areas, including biology, chemistry, epidemiology, mechanics, microelectronics, economics, and finance. This course studies the theory and applications of stochastic differential equations, the design and implementation of numerical methods for solving these practical mathematical equations. The course will start with a background knowledge of random variables, Brownian motion, Ornstein-Uhlenbeck process. Other topics include: stochastic integrals, the Euler-Maruyama method, Milstein's higher order method, stability and convergence.

Algorithms from numerical linear algebra are ubiquitous in scientific and statistical software. The theoretical component of the course aims to impart an understanding of how these algorithms work as well as an appreciation of their potential limitations. Familiar pencil-and-paper methods suitable for solving small problems by hand calculation must typically be modified or replaced by different approaches when faced with large problems whose solution is feasible only with the help of a computer. To illustrate the applications of numerical linear algebra, a variety of examples from statistics, data science and applied mathematics are described. The course includes a substantial computing component providing practical experience with widely used software libraries.

contentlets.description: Algorithms from numerical linear algebra are ubiquitous in scientific and statistical software. The theoretical component of the course aims to impart an understanding of how these algorithms work as well as an appreciation of their potential limitations. Familiar pencil-and-paper methods suitable for solving small problems by hand calculation must typically be modified or replaced by different approaches when faced with large problems whose solution is feasible only with the help of a computer. To illustrate the applications of numerical linear algebra, a variety of examples from statistics, data science and applied mathematics are described. The course includes a substantial computing component providing practical experience with widely used software libraries.
contentlets.title: Numerical Linear Algebra

contentlets.description:
Various aspects of graph theory, including: matchings, coverings and packings, connectivity, graph colourings, planar graphs, extremal graphs and Ramsey theory, the probabilistic method, random graphs.

Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5505 - Combinatorics","description":"

This course will present beautiful topics from classical combinatorics, including, but not limited to, the Pigeonhole Principle, Ramsey Theory, matching theory, Latin squares, graphs algorithms, the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle, generating functions, and Polya counting.


Pre-requisites: 24 units of level III mathematics or a degree in a numerate discipline or permission of the Head of Department. Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.

Final mark returned to students at end of semester; each student may discuss the final result with the Course Authority under the School's usual rules.

contentlets.description:
This course will present beautiful topics from classical combinatorics, including, but not limited to, the Pigeonhole Principle, Ramsey Theory, matching theory, Latin squares, graphs algorithms, the Inclusion-Exclusion Principle, generating functions, and Polya counting.

Pre-requisites: 24 units of level III mathematics or a degree in a numerate discipline or permission of the Head of Department. Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.
contentlets.title: Combinatorics

Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATH5615","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5615 - Banach and Operator Algebras","description":"

Banach algebras combine the topological features of a Banach space with the algebraic features of a ring. Although other examples will be covered, the main focus will be on examining Banach algebras consisting of continuous linear operators on Hilbert and Banach spaces.


Content: general algebras and topology, with examples of Banach algebras and linear operators. Revision of basic functional analysis; weak topologies and spectra. Functional Calculus. Abelian Banach algebras and application to e.g. harmonic analysis. C* algebras. The Spectral Theorem for normal operators. Invariant subspaces.


Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"f7f68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190b","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"60","description":"

A 2 hour exam on the entire course.

Students may inspect their scripts in line wit hstandard School and UNSW policy.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f7f68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fff68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3bf68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190e","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Weekly Problems","assessment_type":{"label":"Tutorial work","value":"tutorial_work"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Each week, a set of exercises will be made available, with one question designated for independent work and follow up submission. Each submission brings up to 1%, and can add up to 10% (this also means that if a student misses 2 submissions out of 12, they can still gain the full 10% in total).

Returned with feedback with a week. 
 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f7f68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"fff68508dbf9b890be4672f5f396190b","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b3f68508dbf9b890be4672f5f3961912","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

The assignment will be a small research project completed in a team of two to mimic real collaborative work in mathematics. Please note that although the tasks can (and should) be split between team members, each team member will share the responsibility for the entire project. You will also have to give a short (∼ 7 − 8 minutes) presentation in the class. Student's final grade will depend on both the written submission and the presentation: evaluated for both the actual results reported and its clarity.

Topics from: elementary number theory, prime numbers, number theoretic functions, Dirichlet series, prime number theorem, continued fractions, diophantine approximation, quadratic reciprocity, algebraic number theory, class number theorem.

Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.

contentlets.description:
Topics in advanced complex function theory chosen from the following: conformal mappings, analytic continuation, entire and meromorphic functions, elliptic functions, asymptotic methods, integral formulae, harmonic functions, Riemann surfaces.

Pre-requisites: 24 units of level III mathematics or a degree in a numerate discipline or permission of the Head of Department.

Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information. Excluded: MATH3680.

Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"MATH5700","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5700 - Modern Differential Geometry and Topology","description":"

Topology and differential geometry both deal with the study of shape: topology from a continuous and differential geometry from a differentiable viewpoint.


This course begins with an introduction to general topology. We then study curves in space and how they bend and twist, and the topology of curves. We then consider surfaces, studying the first and second fundamental forms introduced by Gauss, the various measures of curvature and what they mean for the external and internal appearance and properties of surfaces. We prove the important Gauss-Bonnet theorem and use it to examine topological properties of surfaces, such as the Euler Characteristic. We finish with a look at the hyperbolic plane and a look forward to general Riemannian geometry.

contentlets.description:
Topology and differential geometry both deal with the study of shape: topology from a continuous and differential geometry from a differentiable viewpoint.

This course begins with an introduction to general topology. We then study curves in space and how they bend and twist, and the topology of curves. We then consider surfaces, studying the first and second fundamental forms introduced by Gauss, the various measures of curvature and what they mean for the external and internal appearance and properties of surfaces. We prove the important Gauss-Bonnet theorem and use it to examine topological properties of surfaces, such as the Euler Characteristic. We finish with a look at the hyperbolic plane and a look forward to general Riemannian geometry.

contentlets.description: Limits and continuity are the central concepts of calculus in one and several variables. These concepts can be extended to quite general situations; the simplest of these is when there is some way of measuring the distance between two objects. Some of the most important examples of these `metric spaces' occur as sets of functions, so this course looks at ways in which one might say that a sequence of functions converges. Taking these ideas one step further, we look at convergence which does not come from a generalized distance function. These are the ideas of point set topology. The course will include topics such as countability, continuity, uniform convergence and compactness, as well as an introduction to the core areas of function analysis. This will include the notions of Banach and Hilbert spaces, including Reproducing Kernel Hilbert Spaces which are important in Applied Mathematics, Statistics and elsewhere.
contentlets.title: Modern Analysis

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5706 - Modern Algebra","description":"

In Modern Algebra we examine some of the basic notions of modern algebra that arose in the late 19th and early 20th century. The most fundamental notion is that of a group, which is how mathematicians study symmetry. In this course groups are studied in detail both from an abstract point of view and also to study symmetry in geometry. The other important concept studied is that of a ring. The algebra of adding and multiplying matrices has many similarities with the algebra of numbers. The notion of rings generalises both these two examples. The course examines factorisation theory for certain rings.

contentlets.description: In Modern Algebra we examine some of the basic notions of modern algebra that arose in the late 19th and early 20th century. The most fundamental notion is that of a group, which is how mathematicians study symmetry. In this course groups are studied in detail both from an abstract point of view and also to study symmetry in geometry. The other important concept studied is that of a ring. The algebra of adding and multiplying matrices has many similarities with the algebra of numbers. The notion of rings generalises both these two examples. The course examines factorisation theory for certain rings.
contentlets.title: Modern Algebra

contentlets.description:
Harmonic analysis is the study of functions and measures defined on topological groups (such as the real numbers, the integers or the unit circle). Topics will be chosen from convergence of Fourier series, maximal functions, Fourier transforms, analysis on locally compact abelian groups, characters and dual groups, connections to differential equations and Banach algebras.

Note: Course not offered every year. Contact School for more information.

Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MATH5725 - Galois Theory","description":"

The theory of fields holds the key to questions which frustrated mathematicians for hundreds of years, including the impossibility of squaring a circle or trisecting an angle with ruler and compass, or finding a formula for solving quintic equations. The key to their study involves the Galois group which, loosely speaking, captures the symmetry of the field. Topics covered will include, fields, Eisenstein criterion, field extensions, algebraic extensions, groups of field automorphisms, normal and separable extensions, finite fields, Galois correspondence, solvable groups, solving equations by radicals, ruler and compass constructions, Kummer extensions, Artin-Schreier extensions.


Note: Course not offered every year - contact School for more information.
